## Error Analysis

The error is clear:

**Error**: `Tool 'computer_use_preview' is not supported with gpt-4o-2024-11-20`

**Why this happens**:

The code is trying to use the Computer Use Tool (a relatively new feature) with the GPT-4o model deployment (`gpt-4o-2024-11-20`), but this specific model doesn't support the `computer_use_preview` tool. 

The Computer Use feature requires a model that specifically supports it. Based on the error message and the environment variable name `AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME` defaulting to `"computer-use-preview"`, it appears you need to:

1. **Either**: Deploy a model that supports Computer Use tools in your Azure AI Foundry project
2. **Or**: Update the deployment name to point to a compatible deployment

The issue is on line 18 where it reads:
```csharp
string deploymentName = Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable("AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME") ?? "computer-use-preview";
```

The environment variable is likely not set, so it's defaulting to `"computer-use-preview"`, but your actual deployment is named something else (likely `gpt-4o-2024-11-20` or similar) which doesn't support this tool.

**Solution**: You need to set the `AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME` environment variable to point to a deployment that supports Computer Use tools, or deploy a compatible model in your Azure AI Foundry project.

source.instructions:
# Microsoft Learn MCP Server

This server gives structured access to official Microsoft and Azure documentation via three tools:

## Tools

### microsoft_docs_search
Search official documentation and return up to 10 concise, high-quality content chunks (max 500 tokens each), including title, URL, and excerpt.

- Use first to get a quick, reliable overview
- Ideal for grounding answers in Microsoft knowledge

### microsoft_code_sample_search
Search for code snippets and examples in official Microsoft Learn documentation and return up to 20 relevant, high-quality code samples.

- Use when you need to provide sample Microsoft/Azure related code in your answers.  
- Ideal for generating code snippets or practical implementation examples.  
- Optional parameter `language` can filter results. 

### microsoft_docs_fetch
Fetch and convert full Microsoft documentation pages to markdown.

- Use after search when you need full content from a specific URL
- Required for detailed tutorials, troubleshooting, prerequisites, code samples, or when search results are incomplete or outdated

## Workflow

1. Use `microsoft_docs_search` to find relevant documents.
2. If you need code examples or practical snippets, use `microsoft_code_sample_search`.
3. If deeper or complete information is needed, use `microsoft_docs_fetch`.

**Search gives breadth. Code Sample Search gives practical examples. Fetch gives depth.**

All content comes from Microsoft Learn or official sources, returned in clean markdown format.

This article explains how to deploy and use the latest Claude models in Foundry, including Claude Opus 4.5, Claude Sonnet 4.5, Claude Haiku 4.5, and Claude Opus 4.1. Anthropic's flagship product is Claude, a frontier AI model useful for complex tasks such as coding, agents, financial analysis, research, and office tasks. Claude delivers exceptional performance while maintaining high safety standards.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Available Claude models
Foundry supports Claude Opus 4.5, Claude Sonnet 4.5, Claude Haiku 4.5, and Claude Opus 4.1 models through global standard deployment. These models have key capabilities that include:
1. **Extended thinking**: Extended thinking gives Claude enhanced reasoning capabilities for complex tasks.
2. **Image and text input**: Strong vision capabilities that enable the models to process images and return text outputs for analyzing and understanding charts, graphs, technical diagrams, reports, and other visual assets.
3. **Code generation**: Advanced thinking that includes code generation, analysis, and debugging for Claude Sonnet 4.5 and Claude Opus 4.1.
For more details about the model capabilities, see [capabilities of Claude models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry-classic#anthropic).
#### Claude Opus 4.5 (preview)
Claude Opus 4.5 is Anthropic's most intelligent model, and an industry leader across coding, agents, computer use, and enterprise workflows. With a 200K token context window and 64K max output, Opus 4.5 is ideal for production code, sophisticated agents, office tasks, financial analysis, cybersecurity, and computer use.
#### Claude Sonnet 4.5 (preview)
Claude Sonnet 4.5 is a highly capable model designed for building real-world agents and handling complex, long-horizon tasks. It offers a strong balance of speed and cost for high-volume use cases. Sonnet 4.5 also provides advanced accuracy for computer use, enabling developers to direct Claude to use computers the way people do.
#### Claude Haiku 4.5 (preview)
Claude Haiku 4.5 delivers near-frontier performance for a wide range of use cases. It stands out as one of the best coding and agent models, with the right speed and cost to power free products and scaled sub-agents.
#### Claude Opus 4.1 (preview)
Claude Opus 4.1 is an industry leader for coding. It delivers sustained performance on long-running tasks that require focused effort and thousands of steps, significantly expanding what AI agents can solve.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#available-claude-models"},{"title":"Foundry Models from partners and community","content":"# Foundry Models from partners and community
Note
This document refers to the [Microsoft Foundry (classic)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry-classic#microsoft-foundry-portals) portal.
🔄 [Switch to the Microsoft Foundry (new) documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) if you're using the new portal.
This article lists a selection of Microsoft Foundry Models from partners and community along with their capabilities, [deployment types, and regions of availability](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/deployment-types?view=foundry-classic), excluding [deprecated and legacy models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/model-lifecycle-retirement?view=foundry-classic#deprecated). Most Foundry Models come from partners and community. Trusted third-party organizations, partners, research labs, and community contributors provide these models.
Depending on the [kind of project](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry-classic&preserve-view=true#work-in-a-foundry-project) you use in Azure AI Foundry, you see a different selection of models. To learn more about attributes of Foundry Models from partners and community, see [Explore Foundry Models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/foundry-models-overview?view=foundry-classic#models-from-partners-and-community).
Note
For a list of models sold directly by Azure, see [Foundry Models sold directly by Azure](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-sold-directly-by-azure?view=foundry-classic).
For a list of Azure OpenAI models that are supported by the Foundry Agent Service, see [Models supported by Agent Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic).
## Anthropic
Anthropic's flagship product is Claude, a frontier AI model trusted by leading enterprises and millions of users worldwide for complex tasks including coding, agents, financial analysis, research, and office tasks. Claude delivers exceptional performance while maintaining high safety standards.
To work with Claude models in Foundry, see [Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic).
Claude models are also supported for use in the [Foundry Agent Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"What's new in model router in Microsoft Foundry Models?","content":"# What's new in model router in Microsoft Foundry Models?
This article provides a summary of the latest releases and major documentation updates for Azure model router.
## November 2025
### Anthropic models added
Version `2025-11-18` of model router adds support for three Anthropic models: `claude-haiku-4-5`, `claude-opus-4-1`, and `claude-sonnet-4-5`. To include these in your model router deployment, you need to first deploy them yourself to your Foundry resource (see [Deploy and use Claude models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry&tabs=python)). Then enable them with [model subset configuration](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry) in your model router deployment.
### Model router GA version
A new model router model is now available. Version `2025-11-18` includes support for all underlying models in previous versions, as well as 10 new language models.
It also includes new features that make it more versatile and effective.
1. **Routing profiles** let you skew model router's choices to optimize for quality or cost while maintaining a baseline level of performance.
2. Model router supports **custom subsets**: you can specify which underlying models to include in routing decisions. This gives you more control over cost, compliance, and performance characteristics.
For more information on model router and its capabilities, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic).
## August 2025
### New version of model router (preview)
1. Model router now supports GPT-5 series models.
2. Model router for Microsoft Foundry is a deployable AI chat model that automatically selects the best underlying chat model to respond to a given prompt. For more information on how model router works and its advantages and limitations, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic). To use model router with the Completions API, follow the [How-to guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry-classic).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/whats-new-model-router?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Foundry Models from partners and community","content":"# Foundry Models from partners and community

## Models from Partners and Community
These models constitute the vast majority of the Foundry Models and are provided by trusted third-party organizations, partners, research labs, and community contributors. These models offer specialized and diverse AI capabilities, covering a wide array of scenarios, industries, and innovations. Examples of models from Partners and community are the family of large language models developed by **Anthropic** and **Open models from the Hugging Face hub**.
Anthropic includes Claude family of state-of-the-art large language models that support text and image input, text output, multilingual capabilities, and vision. For help with Anthropic models, use [Microsoft Support](https://aka.ms/anthropic-maas-support). To know more about privacy, use [Anthropic privacy policy](https://aka.ms/anthropic_privacy), and for terms of service, see [Commercial Terms of Service](https://aka.ms/anthropic_tandc). To learn how to work with Anthropic models, see [Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic).
Hugging Face hub includes hundreds of models for real-time inference with managed compute. Hugging Face creates and maintains models listed in this collection. For help with the Hugging Face models, use the [Hugging Face forum](https://discuss.huggingface.co) or [Hugging Face support](https://huggingface.co/support). Learn how to deploy Hugging Face models in [Deploy open models with Azure AI Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/how-to/deploy-models-managed?view=foundry-classic).
Characteristics of Models from Partners and Community:
1. Developed and supported by external partners and community contributors
2. Diverse range of specialized models catering to niche or broad use cases
3. Typically validated by providers themselves, with integration guidelines provided by Azure
4. Community-driven innovation and rapid availability of cutting-edge models
5. Standard Azure AI integration, with support and maintenance managed by the respective providers
Models from Partners and Community are deployable as Managed Compute or serverless API deployment options. The model provider selects how the models are deployable.
### Requesting a model to be included in the model catalog","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/foundry-models-overview?view=foundry-classic#models-from-partners-and-community"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Agent support
1. [Foundry Agent Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic) supports Claude models.
2. [Microsoft Agent Framework](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/agent-framework/user-guide/agents/agent-types/anthropic-agent) supports creating agents that use Claude models.
3. You can build custom AI agents with the [Claude Agent SDK](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/agent-sdk/overview).
## Claude advanced features and capabilities
Claude in Foundry Models supports advanced features and capabilities. **Core capabilities** enhance Claude's fundamental abilities for processing, analyzing, and generating content across various formats and use cases. **Tools** enable Claude to interact with external systems, execute code, and perform automated tasks through various tool interfaces.
Some of the **Core capabilities** that Foundry supports are:
1. **1 million token context window:** An extended context window.
2. **Agent skills:** Extend Claude's capabilities with Skills.
3. **Citations:** Ground Claude's responses in source documents.
4. **Context editing:** Automatically manage conversation context with configurable strategies.
5. **Extended thinking:** Enhanced reasoning capabilities for complex tasks.
6. **PDF support:** Process and analyze text and visual content from PDF documents.
7. **Prompt caching:** Provide Claude with more background knowledge and example outputs to reduce costs and latency.
Some of the **Tools** that Foundry supports are:
1. **MCP connector:** Connect to remote MCP servers directly from the Messages API without a separate MCP client.
2. **Memory:** Store and retrieve information across conversations. Build knowledge bases over time, maintain project context, and learn from past interactions.
3. **Web fetch:** Retrieve full content from specified web pages and PDF documents for in-depth analysis.
For a full list of the supported capabilities and tools, see [Claude's features overview](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/overview).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#agent-support"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Work with Claude models
Once deployed, you have some options for interacting with Claude models to generate text responses:
1. Use the [Anthropic SDKs](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/client-sdks) and the following Claude APIs:
1.1. [Messages API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/messages) to send a structured list of input messages with text and/or image content, and the model generates the next message in the conversation.
1.2. [Token Count API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/messages-count-tokens) to count the number of tokens in a message.
1.3. [Files API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/files-create) to upload and manage files to use with the Claude API without having to re-upload content with each request.
1.4. [Skills API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/skills/create-skill) to create custom skills for Claude AI.
2. Use the [Responses API to generate text responses](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/generate-responses?view=foundry-classic) with Claude models in Microsoft Foundry. For multi-language code samples that demonstrate this usage, see [Use Claude Models with OpenAI Responses API in Microsoft Foundry](https://github.com/Azure-Samples/claude-with-openai-responses).
### Use the Messages API to work with Claude models
The following examples show how to **use the Messages API** to send requests to Claude Sonnet 4.5, by using both Microsoft Entra ID authentication and API key authentication methods. To work with your deployed model, you need these items:
1. Your base URL, which is of the form `https://<resource name>.services.ai.azure.com/anthropic`.
2. Your target URI from your deployment details, which is of the form `https://<resource name>.services.ai.azure.com/anthropic/v1/messages`.
3. Microsoft Entra ID for keyless authentication or your deployment's API key for API authentication.
4. Deployment name you chose during deployment creation. This name can be different from the model ID.
**Python**
#### Use Microsoft Entra ID authentication
For Messages API endpoints, use your base URL with Microsoft Entra ID authentication.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#work-with-claude-models"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)

source.instructions:
# Microsoft Learn MCP Server

This server gives structured access to official Microsoft and Azure documentation via three tools:

## Tools

### microsoft_docs_search
Search official documentation and return up to 10 concise, high-quality content chunks (max 500 tokens each), including title, URL, and excerpt.

- Use first to get a quick, reliable overview
- Ideal for grounding answers in Microsoft knowledge

### microsoft_code_sample_search
Search for code snippets and examples in official Microsoft Learn documentation and return up to 20 relevant, high-quality code samples.

- Use when you need to provide sample Microsoft/Azure related code in your answers.  
- Ideal for generating code snippets or practical implementation examples.  
- Optional parameter `language` can filter results. 

### microsoft_docs_fetch
Fetch and convert full Microsoft documentation pages to markdown.

- Use after search when you need full content from a specific URL
- Required for detailed tutorials, troubleshooting, prerequisites, code samples, or when search results are incomplete or outdated

## Workflow

1. Use `microsoft_docs_search` to find relevant documents.
2. If you need code examples or practical snippets, use `microsoft_code_sample_search`.
3. If deeper or complete information is needed, use `microsoft_docs_fetch`.

**Search gives breadth. Code Sample Search gives practical examples. Fetch gives depth.**

All content comes from Microsoft Learn or official sources, returned in clean markdown format.

This article provides a summary of the latest releases and major documentation updates for Azure model router. ## November 2025 ### Anthropic models added Version `2025-11-18` of model router adds support for three Anthropic models: `claude-haiku-4-5`, `claude-opus-4-1`, and `claude-sonnet-4-5`. Then enable them with [model subset configuration](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry) in your model router deployment. ### Model router GA version A new model router model is now available. Version `2025-11-18` includes support for all underlying models in previous versions, as well as 10 new language models. It also includes new features that make it more versatile and effective. 1. **Routing profiles** let you skew model router's choices to optimize for quality or cost while maintaining a baseline level of performance. 2. Model router supports **custom subsets**: you can specify which underlying models to include in routing decisions. This gives you more control over cost, compliance, and performance characteristics. For more information on model router and its capabilities, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic). ## August 2025 ### New version of model router (preview) 1. In this article, you learn about which regions are available for each of the models supporting serverless API deployments. Important Models that are in preview are marked as *preview* on their model cards in the model catalog. Certain models in the model catalog can be deployed as a serverless API. This kind of deployment provides a way to consume models as an API without hosting them on your subscription, while keeping the enterprise security and compliance that organizations need. This deployment option doesn't require quota from your subscription. This article lists a selection of model offerings and their capabilities, excluding [deprecated and legacy models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/model-lifecycle-retirement?view=foundry-classic#deprecated). ## Region availability Pay-as-you-go billing is available only to users whose Azure subscription belongs to a billing account in a country/region where the model provider has made the offer available (see "offer availability region" in the table in the next section). If the offer is available in the relevant region, the user then must have a Hub/Project in the Azure region where the model is available for deployment or fine-tuning, as applicable (see "Hub/Project Region" columns in the following tables). ### Anthropic models | Model | Hub/Project Region for Deployment | Lifecycle Status| | --- | --- | --- | | Claude Haiku 4.5 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | | Claude Opus 4.1 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | | Claude Sonnet 4.5 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | | Claude Opus 4.5 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | ### Cohere models","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/how-to/deploy-models-serverless-availability?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview) ## rawInput.query: computer use tool Claude Sonnet 4.5 Opus 4.5 supported models Azure AI Foundry

response.value:
Yes! Based on the Microsoft documentation, the **Computer Use tool is supported by these Claude models** in Azure AI Foundry:

1. **Claude Opus 4.5** - Specifically mentioned as "an industry leader across coding, agents, **computer use**, and enterprise workflows"

2. **Claude Sonnet 4.5** - Explicitly states it "provides advanced accuracy for **computer use**, enabling developers to direct Claude to use computers the way people do"

These are the two models that support the Computer Use feature. Claude Haiku 4.5 and Claude Opus 4.1 do **not** support Computer Use according to the documentation.

**To fix your issue**, you need to:

1. Deploy either **Claude Opus 4.5** or **Claude Sonnet 4.5** in your Azure AI Foundry project
2. Set the `AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME` environment variable to the name you give to that deployment

For example, if you deploy Claude Sonnet 4.5 and name it "claude-sonnet-4-5", you would set:
```powershell
$env:AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME = "claude-sonnet-4-5"
```

Claude Sonnet 4.5 would be the recommended choice as it offers a good balance of performance and cost for Computer Use scenarios.

Anthropic's flagship product is Claude, a frontier AI model useful for complex tasks such as coding, agents, financial analysis, research, and office tasks. Claude delivers exceptional performance while maintaining high safety standards.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Available Claude models
Foundry supports Claude Opus 4.5, Claude Sonnet 4.5, Claude Haiku 4.5, and Claude Opus 4.1 models through global standard deployment. These models have key capabilities that include:
1. **Extended thinking**: Extended thinking gives Claude enhanced reasoning capabilities for complex tasks.
2. **Image and text input**: Strong vision capabilities that enable the models to process images and return text outputs for analyzing and understanding charts, graphs, technical diagrams, reports, and other visual assets.
3. **Code generation**: Advanced thinking that includes code generation, analysis, and debugging for Claude Sonnet 4.5 and Claude Opus 4.1.
For more details about the model capabilities, see [capabilities of Claude models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry-classic#anthropic).
#### Claude Opus 4.5 (preview)
Claude Opus 4.5 is Anthropic's most intelligent model, and an industry leader across coding, agents, computer use, and enterprise workflows. With a 200K token context window and 64K max output, Opus 4.5 is ideal for production code, sophisticated agents, office tasks, financial analysis, cybersecurity, and computer use.
#### Claude Sonnet 4.5 (preview)
Claude Sonnet 4.5 is a highly capable model designed for building real-world agents and handling complex, long-horizon tasks. It offers a strong balance of speed and cost for high-volume use cases. Sonnet 4.5 also provides advanced accuracy for computer use, enabling developers to direct Claude to use computers the way people do.
#### Claude Haiku 4.5 (preview)
Claude Haiku 4.5 delivers near-frontier performance for a wide range of use cases. It stands out as one of the best coding and agent models, with the right speed and cost to power free products and scaled sub-agents.
#### Claude Opus 4.1 (preview)
Claude Opus 4.1 is an industry leader for coding. It delivers sustained performance on long-running tasks that require focused effort and thousands of steps, significantly expanding what AI agents can solve.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#available-claude-models"},{"title":"Foundry Models from partners and community","content":"# Foundry Models from partners and community
Note
This document refers to the [Microsoft Foundry (classic)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry-classic#microsoft-foundry-portals) portal.
🔄 [Switch to the Microsoft Foundry (new) documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) if you're using the new portal.
This article lists a selection of Microsoft Foundry Models from partners and community along with their capabilities, [deployment types, and regions of availability](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/deployment-types?view=foundry-classic), excluding [deprecated and legacy models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/model-lifecycle-retirement?view=foundry-classic#deprecated). Most Foundry Models come from partners and community. Trusted third-party organizations, partners, research labs, and community contributors provide these models.
Depending on the [kind of project](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry-classic&preserve-view=true#work-in-a-foundry-project) you use in Azure AI Foundry, you see a different selection of models. To learn more about attributes of Foundry Models from partners and community, see [Explore Foundry Models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/foundry-models-overview?view=foundry-classic#models-from-partners-and-community).
Note
For a list of models sold directly by Azure, see [Foundry Models sold directly by Azure](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-sold-directly-by-azure?view=foundry-classic).
For a list of Azure OpenAI models that are supported by the Foundry Agent Service, see [Models supported by Agent Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic).
## Anthropic
Anthropic's flagship product is Claude, a frontier AI model trusted by leading enterprises and millions of users worldwide for complex tasks including coding, agents, financial analysis, research, and office tasks. Claude delivers exceptional performance while maintaining high safety standards.
To work with Claude models in Foundry, see [Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic).
Claude models are also supported for use in the [Foundry Agent Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"What's new in model router in Microsoft Foundry Models?","content":"# What's new in model router in Microsoft Foundry Models?
This article provides a summary of the latest releases and major documentation updates for Azure model router.
## November 2025
### Anthropic models added
Version `2025-11-18` of model router adds support for three Anthropic models: `claude-haiku-4-5`, `claude-opus-4-1`, and `claude-sonnet-4-5`. To include these in your model router deployment, you need to first deploy them yourself to your Foundry resource (see [Deploy and use Claude models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry&tabs=python)). Then enable them with [model subset configuration](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry) in your model router deployment.
### Model router GA version
A new model router model is now available. Version `2025-11-18` includes support for all underlying models in previous versions, as well as 10 new language models.
It also includes new features that make it more versatile and effective.
1. **Routing profiles** let you skew model router's choices to optimize for quality or cost while maintaining a baseline level of performance.
2. Model router supports **custom subsets**: you can specify which underlying models to include in routing decisions. This gives you more control over cost, compliance, and performance characteristics.
For more information on model router and its capabilities, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic).
## August 2025
### New version of model router (preview)
1. Model router now supports GPT-5 series models.
2. Model router for Microsoft Foundry is a deployable AI chat model that automatically selects the best underlying chat model to respond to a given prompt. For more information on how model router works and its advantages and limitations, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic). To use model router with the Completions API, follow the [How-to guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry-classic).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/whats-new-model-router?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Foundry Models from partners and community","content":"# Foundry Models from partners and community

## Models from Partners and Community
These models constitute the vast majority of the Foundry Models and are provided by trusted third-party organizations, partners, research labs, and community contributors. These models offer specialized and diverse AI capabilities, covering a wide array of scenarios, industries, and innovations. Examples of models from Partners and community are the family of large language models developed by **Anthropic** and **Open models from the Hugging Face hub**.
Anthropic includes Claude family of state-of-the-art large language models that support text and image input, text output, multilingual capabilities, and vision. For help with Anthropic models, use [Microsoft Support](https://aka.ms/anthropic-maas-support). To know more about privacy, use [Anthropic privacy policy](https://aka.ms/anthropic_privacy), and for terms of service, see [Commercial Terms of Service](https://aka.ms/anthropic_tandc). To learn how to work with Anthropic models, see [Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic).
Hugging Face hub includes hundreds of models for real-time inference with managed compute. Hugging Face creates and maintains models listed in this collection. For help with the Hugging Face models, use the [Hugging Face forum](https://discuss.huggingface.co) or [Hugging Face support](https://huggingface.co/support). Learn how to deploy Hugging Face models in [Deploy open models with Azure AI Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/how-to/deploy-models-managed?view=foundry-classic).
Characteristics of Models from Partners and Community:
1. Developed and supported by external partners and community contributors
2. Diverse range of specialized models catering to niche or broad use cases
3. Typically validated by providers themselves, with integration guidelines provided by Azure
4. Community-driven innovation and rapid availability of cutting-edge models
5. Standard Azure AI integration, with support and maintenance managed by the respective providers
Models from Partners and Community are deployable as Managed Compute or serverless API deployment options. The model provider selects how the models are deployable.
### Requesting a model to be included in the model catalog","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/foundry-models-overview?view=foundry-classic#models-from-partners-and-community"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Agent support
1. [Foundry Agent Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic) supports Claude models.
2. [Microsoft Agent Framework](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/agent-framework/user-guide/agents/agent-types/anthropic-agent) supports creating agents that use Claude models.
3. You can build custom AI agents with the [Claude Agent SDK](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/agent-sdk/overview).
## Claude advanced features and capabilities
Claude in Foundry Models supports advanced features and capabilities. **Core capabilities** enhance Claude's fundamental abilities for processing, analyzing, and generating content across various formats and use cases. **Tools** enable Claude to interact with external systems, execute code, and perform automated tasks through various tool interfaces.
Some of the **Core capabilities** that Foundry supports are:
1. **1 million token context window:** An extended context window.
2. **Agent skills:** Extend Claude's capabilities with Skills.
3. **Citations:** Ground Claude's responses in source documents.
4. **Context editing:** Automatically manage conversation context with configurable strategies.
5. **Extended thinking:** Enhanced reasoning capabilities for complex tasks.
6. **PDF support:** Process and analyze text and visual content from PDF documents.
7. **Prompt caching:** Provide Claude with more background knowledge and example outputs to reduce costs and latency.
Some of the **Tools** that Foundry supports are:
1. **MCP connector:** Connect to remote MCP servers directly from the Messages API without a separate MCP client.
2. **Memory:** Store and retrieve information across conversations. Build knowledge bases over time, maintain project context, and learn from past interactions.
3. **Web fetch:** Retrieve full content from specified web pages and PDF documents for in-depth analysis.
For a full list of the supported capabilities and tools, see [Claude's features overview](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/overview).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#agent-support"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Work with Claude models
Once deployed, you have some options for interacting with Claude models to generate text responses:
1. Use the [Anthropic SDKs](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/client-sdks) and the following Claude APIs:
1.1. [Messages API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/messages) to send a structured list of input messages with text and/or image content, and the model generates the next message in the conversation.
1.2. [Token Count API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/messages-count-tokens) to count the number of tokens in a message.
1.3. [Files API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/files-create) to upload and manage files to use with the Claude API without having to re-upload content with each request.
1.4. [Skills API](https://docs.claude.com/en/api/skills/create-skill) to create custom skills for Claude AI.
2. Use the [Responses API to generate text responses](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/generate-responses?view=foundry-classic) with Claude models in Microsoft Foundry. For multi-language code samples that demonstrate this usage, see [Use Claude Models with OpenAI Responses API in Microsoft Foundry](https://github.com/Azure-Samples/claude-with-openai-responses).
### Use the Messages API to work with Claude models
The following examples show how to **use the Messages API** to send requests to Claude Sonnet 4.5, by using both Microsoft Entra ID authentication and API key authentication methods. To work with your deployed model, you need these items:
1. Your base URL, which is of the form `https://<resource name>.services.ai.azure.com/anthropic`.
2. Your target URI from your deployment details, which is of the form `https://<resource name>.services.ai.azure.com/anthropic/v1/messages`.
3. Microsoft Entra ID for keyless authentication or your deployment's API key for API authentication.
4. Deployment name you chose during deployment creation. This name can be different from the model ID.
**Python**
#### Use Microsoft Entra ID authentication
For Messages API endpoints, use your base URL with Microsoft Entra ID authentication.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#work-with-claude-models"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)
## Work with Claude models
```bash
 export AZURE_CLIENT_ID="<AZURE_CLIENT_ID>"
 export AZURE_TENANT_ID="<AZURE_TENANT_ID>"
 export AZURE_CLIENT_SECRET="<AZURE_CLIENT_SECRET>"
```
2. **Install dependencies**
2.1. Install [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) 20 LTS or later ([non-EOL](https://endoflife.date/nodejs)) versions.
2.2. Copy the following lines of text and save them as a file `package.json` inside your folder.
```json
 {
   "type": "module",
   "dependencies": {
     "@anthropic-ai/sdk": "latest",
     "@azure/identity": "latest"
   }
 }
```
 Note
 @azure/core-sse is only needed when you stream the response.
2.3. Open a terminal window in this folder and run `npm install`.
2.4. For each of the code snippets that follow, copy the content into a file `sample.js` and run with `node sample.js`.
3. **Run a basic code sample.** This sample completes the following tasks:
3.1. Creates a client with the Anthropic SDK, using Microsoft Entra ID authentication.
3.2. Makes a basic call to the Messages API. The call is synchronous.
#### Use API key authentication
For Messages API endpoints, use your base URL and API key to authenticate against the service.
1. **Install dependencies**
1.1. Install [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) 20 LTS or later ([non-EOL](https://endoflife.date/nodejs)) versions.

```json

     "@anthropic-ai/sdk": "latest"
   }
 }
```

2.1. Creates a client with the Anthropic SDK by passing your API key to the SDK's configuration. This authentication method lets you interact seamlessly with the service.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#work-with-claude-models"}]

Claude delivers exceptional performance while maintaining high safety standards.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Supported models in Foundry Agent Service","content":"# Supported models in Foundry Agent Service ## Other model collections The following [models sold directly by Azure](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-sold-directly-by-azure?view=foundry-classic&pivots=azure-direct-others) are available for your agents to use: 1. **MAI-DS-R1**: Deterministic, precision-focused reasoning. 2. **grok-4**: Frontier-scale reasoning for complex, multiple-step problem solving. 3. **grok-4-fast-reasoning**: Accelerated agentic reasoning optimized for workflow automation. 4. **grok-4-fast-non-reasoning**: High-throughput, low-latency generation and system routing. 5. **grok-3**: Strong reasoning for complex, system-level workflows. 6. **grok-3-mini**: Lightweight model optimized for interactive, high-volume use cases. 7. **Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct**: Versatile model for enterprise Q&A, decision support, and system orchestration. 8. **Llama-4-Maverick-17B-128E-Instruct-FP8**: FP8-optimized model that delivers fast, cost-efficient inference. 9. **DeepSeek-V3-0324**: Multimodal understanding across text and images. 10. **DeepSeek-V3.1**: Enhanced multimodal reasoning and grounded retrieval. 11. **DeepSeek-R1-0528**: Advanced long-form and multiple-step reasoning. 12. **gpt-oss-120b**: Open-ecosystem model that supports transparency and reproducibility. The following [models from partners](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry-classic) are available for your agents to use: 1. **Claude-Opus-4-1**: Frontier reasoning for the most complex problem-solving. 2. **Claude-Sonnet-4-5**: Balanced performance for multimodal and agentic workflows. 3. **Claude-Haiku-4-5**: Lightweight, high-speed generation for interactive scenarios.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/model-region-support?view=foundry-classic#other-model-collections"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview) ## Best practices Follow these best practices when working with Claude models in Foundry: #### Model selection Choose the appropriate Claude model based on your specific requirements: 1. **Claude Opus 4.5**: For best performance across coding, agents, computer use, and enterprise workflows 2. **Claude Sonnet 4.5**: For balanced performance and capabilities, production workflows 3. **Claude Haiku 4.5**: For speed and cost optimization, high-volume processing 4. **Claude Opus 4.1**: For complex reasoning and enterprise applications #### Prompt engineering 1. **Clear instructions**: Provide specific and detailed prompts 2. **Context management**: Effectively use the available context window 3. **Role definitions**: Use system messages to define the assistant's role and behavior 4. **Structured prompts**: Use consistent formatting for better results #### Cost optimization 1. **Token management**: Monitor and optimize token usage 2. **Model selection**: Use the most cost-effective model for your use case 3. **Caching**: Implement [explicit prompt caching](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompt-caching#continuing-a-multi-turn-conversation) where appropriate 4. **Request batching**: Combine multiple requests when possible","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#best-practices"},{"title":"Use foundation models","content":"# Use foundation models ## Foundation model types | Task type | Description | Supported models | When to use? Recommended use cases| | --- | --- | --- | --- | | [Reasoning](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/model-serving/query-reason-models) | Advanced AI systems designed to simulate human-like logical thinking. Reasoning models integrate techniques such as symbolic logic, probabilistic reasoning, and neural networks to analyze context, break down tasks, and explain their decision-making. | The following are supported Databricks-hosted foundation model:
- [`databricks-gpt-oss-20B`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/supported-models#openai-gpt-20b)
- [`databricks-gpt-oss-120B`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/supported-models#openai-gpt-120b)
- [`databricks-claude-sonnet-4-5`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/supported-models#claude-sonnet-4-5)
- [`databricks-claude-sonnet-4`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/supported-models#claude-sonnet-4)
- [`databricks-claude-opus-4-1`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/supported-models#claude-opus-4-1)
- [`databricks-claude-3.7-sonnet`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/supported-models#claude-sonnet)

The following are supported external models:
- OpenAI models with reasoning capabilities
- Anthropic Claude models with reasoning capabilities
- Google Gemini models with reasoning capabilities | Recommended wherever automated, accurate, and scalable analysis of visual information is needed:
- Code generation
- Content creation and summarization
- Agent orchestration | ## Function calling Databricks Function Calling is OpenAI-compatible and is only available during model serving as part of [Foundation Model APIs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/) and serving endpoints that serve [external models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/generative-ai/external-models/). For details, see [Function calling on Azure Databricks](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/model-serving/function-calling). ## Structured outputs Structured outputs is OpenAI-compatible and is only available during model serving as part of [Foundation Model APIs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/foundation-model-apis/). For details, see [Structured outputs on Azure Databricks](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/model-serving/structured-outputs).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/machine-learning/model-serving/score-foundation-models#foundation-model-types"},{"title":"Model router for Microsoft Foundry","content":"# Model router for Microsoft Foundry ## Underlying models With the `2025-11-18` version, Model Router adds nine new models including Anthropic's Claude, DeepSeek, Llama, Grok models to support a total of 18 models available for routing your prompts. | Model router version | Underlying models | Underlying model version| | --- | --- | --- | | `2025-11-18` | `gpt-4.1``gpt-4.1-mini``gpt-4.1-nano``o4-mini``gpt-5-nano``gpt-5-mini``gpt-5``gpt-5-chat``Deepseek-v3.1``gpt-oss-120b``llama4-maverick-instruct``grok-4``grok-4-fast``gpt-4o``gpt-4o-mini``claude-haiku-4-5``claude-opus-4-1``claude-sonnet-4-5` | `2025-04-14``2025-04-14``2025-04-14``2025-04-16``2025-08-07``2025-08-07``2025-08-07``2025-08-07` N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A `2024-11-20``2024-07-18``2025-10-01``2025-08-05``2025-09-29` | | `2025-08-07` | `gpt-4.1``gpt-4.1-mini``gpt-4.1-nano``o4-mini``gpt-5``gpt-5-mini``gpt-5-nano``gpt-5-chat` | `2025-04-14``2025-04-14``2025-04-14``2025-04-16``2025-08-07``2025-08-07``2025-08-07``2025-08-07` | | `2025-05-19` | `gpt-4.1``gpt-4.1-mini``gpt-4.1-nano``o4-mini` | `2025-04-14``2025-04-14``2025-04-14``2025-04-16` | ","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic#underlying-models"},{"title":"What's new in model router in Microsoft Foundry Models?","content":"# What's new in model router in Microsoft Foundry Models? This article provides a summary of the latest releases and major documentation updates for Azure model router. ## November 2025 ### Anthropic models added Version `2025-11-18` of model router adds support for three Anthropic models: `claude-haiku-4-5`, `claude-opus-4-1`, and `claude-sonnet-4-5`. To include these in your model router deployment, you need to first deploy them yourself to your Foundry resource (see [Deploy and use Claude models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry&tabs=python)). Then enable them with [model subset configuration](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry) in your model router deployment. ### Model router GA version A new model router model is now available. Version `2025-11-18` includes support for all underlying models in previous versions, as well as 10 new language models. It also includes new features that make it more versatile and effective. 1. **Routing profiles** let you skew model router's choices to optimize for quality or cost while maintaining a baseline level of performance. 2. Model router supports **custom subsets**: you can specify which underlying models to include in routing decisions. This gives you more control over cost, compliance, and performance characteristics. For more information on model router and its capabilities, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic). ## August 2025 ### New version of model router (preview) 1. Model router now supports GPT-5 series models. 2. Model router for Microsoft Foundry is a deployable AI chat model that automatically selects the best underlying chat model to respond to a given prompt. For more information on how model router works and its advantages and limitations, see the [Model router concepts guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/concepts/model-router?view=foundry-classic). To use model router with the Completions API, follow the [How-to guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/openai/how-to/model-router?view=foundry-classic).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/whats-new-model-router?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Foundry Models from partners and community","content":"# Foundry Models from partners and community ## Anthropic | Model | Type | Capabilities | Project type| | --- | --- | --- | --- | | [claude-haiku-4-5](https://aka.ms/claude-haiku-4-5)**(Preview)** | Messages | - **Input:** text and image - **Output:** text (64,000 max tokens) - **Context window:** 200,000 - **Languages:**`en`, `fr`, `ar`, `zh`, `ja`, `ko`, `es`, `hi` - **Tool calling:** Yes (file search and code execution) - **Response formats:** Text, JSON | Foundry, Hub-based | | [claude-opus-4-1](https://aka.ms/claude-opus-4-1)**(Preview)** | Messages | - **Input:** text, image, and code - **Output:** text (32,000 max tokens) - **Context window:** 200,000 - **Languages:**`en`, `fr`, `ar`, `zh`, `ja`, `ko`, `es`, `hi` - **Tool calling:** Yes (file search and code execution) - **Response formats:** Text, JSON | Foundry, Hub-based | | [claude-sonnet-4-5](https://aka.ms/claude-sonnet-4-5)**(Preview)** | Messages | - **Input:** text, image, and code - **Output:** text (max 64,000 tokens) - **Context window:** 200,000 - **Languages:**`en`, `fr`, `ar`, `zh`, `ja`, `ko`, `es`, `hi` - **Tool calling:** Yes (file search and code execution) - **Response formats:** Text, JSON | Foundry, Hub-based | | [claude-opus-4-5](https://aka.ms/claude-opus-4-5)**(Preview)** | Messages | - **Input:** text and imag, and code - **Output:** text (64,000 max tokens) - **Context window:** 200,000 - **Languages:**`en`, `fr`, `ar`, `zh`, `ja`, `ko`, `es`, `hi` - **Tool calling:** Yes (file search and code execution) - **Response formats:** Text, JSON | Foundry, Hub-based | See [the Anthropic model collection in the Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com/explore/models?&selectedCollection=anthropic/?cid=learnDocs).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/concepts/models-from-partners?view=foundry-classic#anthropic"},{"title":"Region availability for models in serverless APIs","content":"# Region availability for models in serverless APIs Note This document refers to the [Microsoft Foundry (classic)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry-classic#microsoft-foundry-portals) portal. 🔍 [View the Microsoft Foundry (new) documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) to learn about the new portal. In this article, you learn about which regions are available for each of the models supporting serverless API deployments. Important Models that are in preview are marked as *preview* on their model cards in the model catalog. Certain models in the model catalog can be deployed as a serverless API. This kind of deployment provides a way to consume models as an API without hosting them on your subscription, while keeping the enterprise security and compliance that organizations need. This deployment option doesn't require quota from your subscription. This article lists a selection of model offerings and their capabilities, excluding [deprecated and legacy models](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/concepts/model-lifecycle-retirement?view=foundry-classic#deprecated). ## Region availability Pay-as-you-go billing is available only to users whose Azure subscription belongs to a billing account in a country/region where the model provider has made the offer available (see "offer availability region" in the table in the next section). If the offer is available in the relevant region, the user then must have a Hub/Project in the Azure region where the model is available for deployment or fine-tuning, as applicable (see "Hub/Project Region" columns in the following tables). ### Anthropic models | Model | Hub/Project Region for Deployment | Lifecycle Status| | --- | --- | --- | | Claude Haiku 4.5 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | | Claude Opus 4.1 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | | Claude Sonnet 4.5 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | | Claude Opus 4.5 | East US 2 Sweden Central | Preview | ### Cohere models","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/how-to/deploy-models-serverless-availability?view=foundry-classic"},{"title":"Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview)","content":"# Deploy and use Claude models in Microsoft Foundry (preview) ## API quotas and limits Claude models in Foundry have the following rate limits, measured in Tokens Per Minute (TPM) and Requests Per Minute (RPM): | Model | Deployment Type | Default RPM | Default TPM | Enterprise and MCA-E RPM | Enterprise and MCA-E TPM| | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | claude-haiku-4-5 | GlobalStandard | 1,000 | 1,000,000 | 4,000 | 4,000,000 | | claude-opus-4-1 | GlobalStandard | 1,000 | 1,000,000 | 2,000 | 2,000,000 | | claude-sonnet-4-5 | GlobalStandard | 1,000 | 1,000,000 | 4,000 | 2,000,000 | | claude-opus-4-5 | Global Standard | 1,000 | 1,000,000 | 2,000 | 2,000,000 | To increase your quota beyond the default limits, submit a request through the [quota increase request form](https://aka.ms/oai/stuquotarequest). ### Rate limit best practices To optimize your usage and avoid rate limiting: 1. **Implement retry logic**: Handle 429 responses with exponential backoff 2. **Batch requests**: Combine multiple prompts when possible 3. **Monitor usage**: Track your token consumption and request patterns 4. **Use appropriate models**: Choose the right Claude model for your use case","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/foundry-models/how-to/use-foundry-models-claude?view=foundry-classic#api-quotas-and-limits"}]

response.value: Let me check line 20 in the
file.

Line 20 (`string deploymentName = "computer-use-preview";`) is problematic because:

**The literal string "computer-use-preview" is not an actual deployment name** - it's just a placeholder/example name. This won't match any real deployment in your Azure AI Foundry project.

When you hardcode it like this for testing, you're bypassing the environment variable entirely. The code will **always** use "computer-use-preview" regardless of what deployment you actually have.

**What you should do instead:**

1. **Deploy** Claude Sonnet 4.5 or Claude Opus 4.5 in your Azure AI Foundry project
2. Use the **actual deployment name** you create (e.g., "claude-sonnet-4-5", "my-computer-use-model", etc.)
3. Either:
   - Set the environment variable:
- OR temporarily hardcode your **actual** deployment name:

The error you're getting indicates your project probably has a GPT-4o deployment (maybe even named "computer-use-preview"), but GPT-4o doesn't support the Computer Use tool - only Claude Opus 4.5 and Claude Sonnet 4.5 do.

So while hardcoding values during testing is fine, you need to hardcode a **real, valid deployment name** that points to a model that actually supports Computer Use.

toolCallRounds.response:
Line 20 (`string deploymentName = "computer-use-preview";`) is problematic because:

**The literal string "computer-use-preview" is not an actual deployment name** - it's just a placeholder/example name. This won't match any real deployment in your Azure AI Foundry project.

When you hardcode it like this for testing, you're bypassing the environment variable entirely. The code will **always** use "computer-use-preview" regardless of what deployment you actually have.

**What you should do instead:**

1. **Deploy** Claude Sonnet 4.5 or Claude Opus 4.5 in your Azure AI Foundry project
2. Use the **actual deployment name** you create (e.g., "claude-sonnet-4-5", "my-computer-use-model", etc.)
3. Either:
   - Set the environment variable: `$env:AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME = "your-actual-deployment-name"`
   - OR temporarily hardcode your **actual** deployment name: `string deploymentName = "your-actual-deployment-name";`

The error you're getting indicates your project probably has a GPT-4o deployment (maybe even named "computer-use-preview"), but GPT-4o doesn't support the Computer Use tool - only Claude Opus 4.5 and Claude Sonnet 4.5 do.

So while hardcoding values during testing is fine, you need to hardcode a **real, valid deployment name** that points to a model that actually supports Computer Use.

response.value: Let me read through the entire program to understand what it's doing:

This program is a **demonstration of Claude's Computer Use feature** - teaching an AI agent to control a computer like a human would. Specifically:

## What it does:

1. **Creates an AI agent** with "Computer Use" capabilities using Claude (Opus 4.5 or Sonnet 4.5)

2. **Simulates a web search task**: The agent is asked to search for "OpenAI news" on Bing

3. **Shows the agent screenshots** and lets it decide what actions to take (like a human looking at a screen)

4. **Processes the agent's actions**:
   - **Type**: Agent types text into the search box
   - **Click**: Agent clicks elements 
   - **Key press**: Agent presses Enter to submit the search

5. **Runs in a simulation loop**:
   - Shows agent a screenshot (starting with Bing search page)
   - Agent decides what to do (e.g., "type 'OpenAI news'")
   - Simulates the action and provides next screenshot (e.g., search box with text)
   - Agent sees new screenshot and decides next step (e.g., "press Enter")
   - Shows results page
   - Task complete!

## The clever part:

It's **simulating** computer interaction using pre-made screenshots from the

folder rather than actually controlling a browser. This demonstrates how Computer Use works without needing actual screen control infrastructure.

The agent sees the screenshots, reasons about what to do next (type, click, press keys), and the simulation transitions through states: **Initial â†’ Typed â†’ PressedEnter â†’ Results**.

It's essentially teaching AI to use computers the way humans do - by looking at screens and performing keyboard/mouse actions!

toolCallRounds.response:
This program is a **demonstration of Claude's Computer Use feature** - teaching an AI agent to control a computer like a human would. Specifically:

## What it does:

1. **Creates an AI agent** with "Computer Use" capabilities using Claude (Opus 4.5 or Sonnet 4.5)

2. **Simulates a web search task**: The agent is asked to search for "OpenAI news" on Bing

3. **Shows the agent screenshots** and lets it decide what actions to take (like a human looking at a screen)

4. **Processes the agent's actions**:
   - **Type**: Agent types text into the search box
   - **Click**: Agent clicks elements 
   - **Key press**: Agent presses Enter to submit the search

5. **Runs in a simulation loop**:
   - Shows agent a screenshot (starting with Bing search page)
   - Agent decides what to do (e.g., "type 'OpenAI news'")
   - Simulates the action and provides next screenshot (e.g., search box with text)
   - Agent sees new screenshot and decides next step (e.g., "press Enter")
   - Shows results page
   - Task complete!

## The clever part:

It's **simulating** computer interaction using pre-made screenshots from the `Assets` folder rather than actually controlling a browser. This demonstrates how Computer Use works without needing actual screen control infrastructure.

The agent sees the screenshots, reasons about what to do next (type, click, press keys), and the simulation transitions through states: **Initial â†’ Typed â†’ PressedEnter â†’ Results**.

It's essentially teaching AI to use computers the way humans do - by looking at screens and performing keyboard/mouse actions!

// Copyright (c) Microsoft. All rights reserved.

// This sample shows how to use Computer Use Tool with AI Agents.

using Azure.AI.Projects;
using Azure.AI.Projects.OpenAI;
using Azure.Identity;
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;
using Microsoft.Extensions.AI;
using OpenAI.Responses;

namespace Demo.ComputerUse;

internal sealed class Program
{
    private static async Task Main(string[] args)
    {
        string endpoint = Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable("AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_ENDPOINT") ?? throw new InvalidOperationException("AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_ENDPOINT is not set.");
        // string deploymentName = Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable("AZURE_FOUNDRY_PROJECT_DEPLOYMENT_NAME") ?? "computer-use-preview";
        const string DeploymentName = "computer-use-preview";

        // Get a client to create/retrieve/delete server side agents with Azure Foundry Agents.
        AIProjectClient aiProjectClient = new(new Uri(endpoint), new AzureCliCredential());
        const string AgentInstructions = @"
                    You are a computer automation assistant. 
                    
                    Be direct and efficient. When you reach the search results page, read and describe the actual search result titles and descriptions you can see.
                ";

        const string AgentNameMEAI = "ComputerAgent-MEAI";
        const string AgentNameNative = "ComputerAgent-NATIVE";

        // Option 1 - Using ComputerUseTool + AgentOptions (MEAI + AgentFramework)
        // Create AIAgent directly
        AIAgent agentOption1 = await aiProjectClient.CreateAIAgentAsync(
            name: AgentNameMEAI,
            model: DeploymentName,
            instructions: AgentInstructions,
            description: "Computer automation agent with screen interaction capabilities.",
            tools: [
                    ResponseTool.CreateComputerTool(ComputerToolEnvironment.Browser, 1026, 769).AsAITool(),
                ]);

        // Option 2 - Using PromptAgentDefinition SDK native type
        // Create the server side agent version
        AIAgent agentOption2 = await aiProjectClient.CreateAIAgentAsync(
            name: AgentNameNative,
            creationOptions: new AgentVersionCreationOptions(
                new PromptAgentDefinition(model: DeploymentName)
                {
                    Instructions = AgentInstructions,
                    Tools = { ResponseTool.CreateComputerTool(
                environment: new ComputerToolEnvironment("windows"),
                displayWidth: 1026,
                displayHeight: 769) }
                })
        );

        // Either invoke option1 or option2 agent, should have same result
        // Option 1
        await InvokeComputerUseAgentAsync(agentOption1);

        // Option 2
        //await InvokeComputerUseAgentAsync(agentOption2);

        // Cleanup by agent name removes the agent version created.
        await aiProjectClient.Agents.DeleteAgentAsync(agentOption1.Name);
        await aiProjectClient.Agents.DeleteAgentAsync(agentOption2.Name);
    }

    private static async Task InvokeComputerUseAgentAsync(AIAgent agent)
    {
        // Load screenshot assets
        Dictionary<string, byte[]> screenshots = ComputerUseUtil.LoadScreenshotAssets();

        ChatOptions chatOptions = new();
        ResponseCreationOptions responseCreationOptions = new()
        {
            TruncationMode = ResponseTruncationMode.Auto
        };
        chatOptions.RawRepresentationFactory = (_) => responseCreationOptions;
        ChatClientAgentRunOptions runOptions = new(chatOptions)
        {
            AllowBackgroundResponses = true,
        };

        AgentThread thread = agent.GetNewThread();

        ChatMessage message = new(ChatRole.User, [
            new TextContent("I need you to help me search for 'OpenAI news'. Please type 'OpenAI news' and submit the search. Once you see search results, the task is complete."),
            new DataContent(new BinaryData(screenshots["browser_search"]), "image/png")
        ]);

        // Initial request with screenshot - start with Bing search page
        Console.WriteLine("Starting computer automation session (initial screenshot: cua_browser_search.png)...");

        AgentRunResponse runResponse = await agent.RunAsync(message, thread: thread, options: runOptions);

        // Main interaction loop
        const int MaxIterations = 10;
        int iteration = 0;
        // Initialize state machine
        SearchState currentState = SearchState.Initial;
        string initialCallId = string.Empty;

        while (true)
        {
            // Poll until the response is complete.
            while (runResponse.ContinuationToken is { } token)
            {
                // Wait before polling again.
                await Task.Delay(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(2));

                // Continue with the token.
                runOptions.ContinuationToken = token;

                runResponse = await agent.RunAsync(thread, runOptions);
            }

            Console.WriteLine($"Agent response received (ID: {runResponse.ResponseId})");

            if (iteration >= MaxIterations)
            {
                Console.WriteLine($"\nReached maximum iterations ({MaxIterations}). Stopping.");
                break;
            }

            iteration++;
            Console.WriteLine($"\n--- Iteration {iteration} ---");

            // Check for computer calls in the response
            IEnumerable<ComputerCallResponseItem> computerCallResponseItems = runResponse.Messages
                .SelectMany(x => x.Contents)
                .Where(c => c.RawRepresentation is ComputerCallResponseItem and not null)
                .Select(c => (ComputerCallResponseItem)c.RawRepresentation!);

            ComputerCallResponseItem? firstComputerCall = computerCallResponseItems.FirstOrDefault();
            if (firstComputerCall is null)
            {
                Console.WriteLine("No computer call actions found. Ending interaction.");
                Console.WriteLine($"Final Response: {runResponse}");
                break;
            }

            // Process the first computer call response
            ComputerCallAction action = firstComputerCall.Action;
            string currentCallId = firstComputerCall.CallId;

            // Set the initial computer call ID for tracking and subsequent responses.
            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(initialCallId))
            {
                initialCallId = currentCallId;
            }

            Console.WriteLine($"Processing computer call (ID: {currentCallId})");

            // Show what the agent decided to do
            Console.WriteLine($"  ðŸ¤– Action: {action.Kind}");
            if (action.TypeText is not null)
            {
                Console.WriteLine($"  ðŸ“ Text to type: '{action.TypeText}'");
            }
            if (action.KeyPressKeyCodes is not null)
            {
                Console.WriteLine($"  âŒ¨ï¸  Keys: {string.Join(", ", action.KeyPressKeyCodes)}");
            }

            // Simulate executing the action and taking a screenshot
            (SearchState CurrentState, byte[] ImageBytes) screenInfo = ComputerUseUtil.HandleComputerActionAndTakeScreenshot(action, currentState, screenshots);
            currentState = screenInfo.CurrentState;

            Console.WriteLine("Sending action result back to agent...");

            AIContent content = new()
            {
                RawRepresentation = new ComputerCallOutputResponseItem(
                    initialCallId,
                    output: ComputerCallOutput.CreateScreenshotOutput(new BinaryData(screenInfo.ImageBytes), "image/png"))
            };

            // Follow-up message with action result and new screenshot
            message = new(ChatRole.User, [content]);
            runResponse = await agent.RunAsync(message, thread: thread, options: runOptions);
        }
    }
}

{"content": "# Real-World Computer Use Cases

## Why Computer Use is Powerful

The current demo uses **static screenshots** for simplicity, but in production, Computer Use enables AI to:

### ðŸŽ¯ **Real Use Cases**

#### 1. **Automated Testing**
- AI navigates your app like a real user
- Finds bugs by exploring different paths
- Takes screenshots of errors automatically
- **Benefit**: Tests scenarios you didn't think to write

#### 2. **Legacy System Automation**
- Many companies have old systems with no APIs
- Computer Use can automate these by "looking" at the screen
- Fill forms, extract data, monitor systems
- **Benefit**: Automate without changing legacy code

#### 3. **Customer Support Automation**
- AI agent helps users navigate complex interfaces
- "Click the blue button in the top right" â†’ AI finds and clicks it
- Works across any application
- **Benefit**: Support for visual tasks, not just text

#### 4. **Data Entry from Images**
- AI looks at scanned forms, invoices, receipts
- Fills database fields by understanding visual layout
- Adapts to different formats automatically
- **Benefit**: No template-based OCR needed

#### 5. **Monitoring & Alerts**
- AI periodically checks dashboards/websites
- Notices anomalies visually (graphs, colors, layouts)
- Can take corrective actions automatically
- **Benefit**: Monitor things that don't have APIs

#### 6. **Accessibility**
- Help users with disabilities navigate interfaces
- AI can read screens and perform actions via voice commands
- Works with any application
- **Benefit**: Universal accessibility layer

## ðŸ”§ **Enhanced Demo Features**

The new `ProgramEnhanced.cs` shows:

### Better Visibility
```
ðŸ’­ Agent's thoughts: I can see a registration form with 6 fields...
ðŸŽ¬ Action: Click
   ðŸ“ Typing: 'John Smith'
   ðŸ“¸ Current state: FillingFields
   ðŸ“ˆ Progress: 1/6 fields completed
```

### Progress Tracking
- Shows which fields are completed
- Displays iteration count
- Shows agent's reasoning

### Real Decision Making
- Agent decides field order
- Validates completion
- Handles errors

## ðŸš€ **Moving to Production**

To use Computer Use with **real** applications:

### Option 1: Browser Automation
```csharp
// Use Playwright or Selenium to capture real screenshots
var page = await browser.NewPageAsync();
await page.GotoAsync("https://yourapp.com");
byte[] screenshot = await page.ScreenshotAsync();

// Send to AI
var response = await agent.RunAsync(
    new ChatMessage(ChatRole.User, [
        new TextContent("Fill the login form"),
        new DataContent(new BinaryData(screenshot), "image/png")
    ])
);

// Execute AI's actions
if (action.TypeText != null)
    await page.TypeAsync("input[name='username']", action.TypeText);
```

### Option 2: Desktop Automation
```csharp
// Capture desktop screenshots
var screen = Screen.PrimaryScreen;
var bitmap = new Bitmap(screen.Bounds.Width, screen.Bounds.Height);
// ... capture screen

// Send to AI and execute mouse/keyboard actions based on response
```

### Option 3: Virtual Desktop/RDP
- AI controls a virtual machine
- Useful for testing, legacy systems
- Complete isolation

## ðŸ“Š **Comparison**

| Approach | Pros | Cons |
|----------|------|------|
| **Static Screenshots (Current Demo)** | Easy to test, fast, predictable | Not real automation |
| **Browser Automation** | Works with any web app, real interactions | Requires browser infrastructure |
| **Desktop Automation** | Works with any GUI app | Platform-specific, needs permissions |
| **API Integration** | Fast, reliable, structured | Requires API to exist |

## ðŸ’¡ **Best Practices**

1. **Start with screenshots** - Validate your prompts work
2. **Add real browser** - Integrate Playwright/Selenium
3. **Error handling** - AI can get confused, add fallbacks
4. **Human-in-loop** - For critical actions, ask confirmation
5. **Logging** - Save screenshots + actions for debugging

## ðŸŽ“ **Learning Path**

1. âœ… Run the basic demo (understand concept)
2. âœ… Run enhanced demo (see better output)
3. ðŸ”„ Add Playwright to take real screenshots
4. ðŸ”„ Execute AI's actions in real browser
5. ðŸ”„ Build your first automation task

The **real power** isn't the screenshots - it's that AI can **understand visual interfaces** and **make decisions** about how to interact with them, just like a human would!

// Task: Navigate to Wikipedia, search for a topic, and extract key information
